verses.text: Then I saw another mighty angel coming down from heaven, wrapped in a cloud, with a rainbow above his head. His face was like the sun, and his legs like pillars of fire.
verses.comment: This vision echoes Old Testament images of divine presence (Ezekiel 1:28, Exodus 13:21). Some interpreters see this mighty angel as symbolizing Christ himself, given the glowing description, while others see him as an angelic messenger bearing God’s authority. The cloud and rainbow represent God's covenant and glorious presence.

verses.text: He held a little scroll open in his hand. He placed his right foot on the sea and his left on the land.
verses.comment: The open scroll contrasts with the sealed scroll of Revelation 5, suggesting its contents are ready to be revealed. The angel’s stance over land and sea indicates authority over all creation (Ezekiel 2:9-10), foreshadowing God's universal dominion.

verses.text: He cried out with a loud voice, like a lion roaring. When he cried out, the seven thunders raised their voices.
verses.comment: The lion’s roar signifies kingly authority and judgment (cf. Amos 3:8; Rev. 5:5). The 'seven thunders' echo the voice of God resounding in power (Psalm 29; see also John 12:28-29), and may symbolize complete, divine revelation. The number seven suggests fullness and perfection.

verses.text: When the seven thunders spoke, I was about to write, but I heard a voice from heaven saying, 'Seal up what the seven thunders have said, and do not write it down.'
verses.comment: Unlike other prophecies that are to be revealed (cf. Rev. 22:10), here John is instructed to withhold this particular message (like Daniel 8:26). This points to God's sovereignty in revelation—some mysteries remain hidden until their time.

verses.text: Then the angel I had seen standing on the sea and the land raised his right hand to heaven.
verses.comment: Raising the right hand signifies a solemn oath (Genesis 14:22; Daniel 12:7), underlining the truth and certainty of the message about to be announced.

verses.text: He swore by him who lives forever and ever, who created heaven and what is in it, the earth and what is in it, and the sea and what is in it, that there will be no more delay.
verses.comment: The angel swears by the eternal Creator (Ex. 20:11; Ps. 146:6), affirming the certainty of fulfillment—there will no longer be any delay in God’s plan. This reflects God’s authority over all creation.

verses.text: But in the days of the sounding of the seventh angel, when he is about to blow his trumpet, the mystery of God will be fulfilled, just as he announced to his servants the prophets.
verses.comment: The 'mystery of God' speaks of God’s hidden plan, now to be revealed and brought to completion (Rom. 16:25-26; 1 Cor. 15:51). This is the culmination of salvation history as foretold by the prophets (cf. Daniel 12:9).

verses.text: Then the voice I had heard from heaven spoke to me again, saying, 'Go, take the opened scroll from the hand of the angel who stands on the sea and the land.'
verses.comment: This command parallels Ezekiel’s call to eat the scroll (Ezek. 3:1-3). The scroll symbolizes John’s prophetic mission to receive and deliver God’s message, reinforcing the importance of receiving revelation directly from God’s agent.

verses.text: So I went to the angel and asked him to give me the little scroll. And he said to me, 'Take it and eat it; it will be bitter in your stomach, but in your mouth it will be as sweet as honey.'
verses.comment: Eating the scroll signifies internalizing God’s message (Ezek. 3:3; Ps. 119:103). The dual taste—sweet as honey, yet bitter—shows God's word brings joy but also can bring suffering or difficult burdens for the prophet and hearers alike.

verses.text: I took the little scroll from the angel’s hand and ate it; it was sweet as honey in my mouth, but when I had eaten it, my stomach turned bitter.
verses.comment: The fulfillment echoes Ezekiel’s experience (Ezek. 3:3). The sweetness of God’s word anticipates blessing and the bitterness forewarns of the suffering or judgment that accompanies prophecy—an ongoing theme for faithful messengers.

verses.text: And I was told, 'You must prophesy again concerning many peoples and nations and languages and kings.'
verses.comment: John’s commission is universal—his prophecy will concern all peoples, reflecting God’s worldwide plan of salvation. This emphasizes the responsibility and continuity in bearing witness to the fullness of God’s message, which must reach all nations (Matt. 28:19-20; see Jer. 1:10).
